result.markdown:
--- title: "Project #2" --- # Set Up For my final project I'm going to be anaylzing the `outer_space_objects` dataset. Let's start by loading it in and looking at the structure of the dataset. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} outer_space_objects ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1,175 × 4 Entity Code Year num_objects 1 APSCO 2023 1 2 Algeria DZA 2002 1 3 Algeria DZA 2010 1 4 Algeria DZA 2016 3 5 Algeria DZA 2017 1 6 Angola AGO 2017 1 7 Angola AGO 2022 1 8 Arabsat 1985 2 9 Arabsat 1992 1 10 Arabsat 1996 2 # ℹ 1,165 more rows ``` ::: ::: It looks like that the dataset is composed of 4 variables and 1175 observations. 1. `Entity`: Entity, country or other entity 2. `Code`: Entity code 3. `Year` 4. `num_objects`: Annual number of objects launched into outer space `Code` seems mostly useless for our purposes, and `Entity` could use some cleaning up, like separating country and other entities to different categories. # Initial Clean Up To start I'm going to separate the `Entity` into countries and other entities, and I'm going to remove the `Code` column.
Looking through the data it appears that the non-country entities are: 1. `APSCO`: The Asia Pacific Space Cooperation Organisation. 2. `Arabsat`: The Arab Satellite Communications Organization. 3. `EUMETSAT`: the European Organisation for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites. 4. `European Space Agency` 5. `European Union` 6. `Eutelsat`: A French Satellite Operator. 7. `Inmarsat`: A British Satellite Operator. 8. `Intelsat`: A Multinational Satellite Operator. 9. `Intersputnik`: Intersputnik International Organization of Space Communications. 10. `NATO` 11. `RASCOM`: Regional African Satellite Communication Organization 12. `Sea Launch`: Multinational Launch Company (defunct). 13. `Starsem`: Russian company made for the Souyez launch. 14. `World`: World data set. Looks like you can categorize these into multinational and private organizations. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} outer_space_objects$Organization <- "Country" outer_space_objects %>% arrange(Code) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1,175 × 5 Entity Code Year num_objects Organization 1 Angola AGO 2017 1 Country 2 Angola AGO 2022 1 Country 3 United Arab Emirates ARE 2000 1 Country 4 United Arab Emirates ARE 2003 1 Country 5 United Arab Emirates ARE 2008 1 Country 6 United Arab Emirates ARE 2009 1 Country 7 United Arab Emirates ARE 2011 1 Country 8 United Arab Emirates ARE 2012 1 Country 9 United Arab Emirates ARE 2013 1 Country 10 United Arab Emirates ARE 2017 1 Country # ℹ 1,165 more rows ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} outer_space_objects$Organization[c(1, 8:18, 222:232, 246:290, 512, 700:704, 764, 765, 1108:1174)] <- "Multinational" outer_space_objects$Organization[c(291:311, 469:511, 843, 904)] <- "Private" outer_space_objects <- outer_space_objects %>% select(-Code) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: # General Observations ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Project2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: The amount of objects launched into space have only significantly increased in the last 15 years, this is almost certainly due to the internet age. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} outer_space_objects2 <- outer_space_objects %>% select(-Year)%>% group_by(Entity)%>% summarise(across(num_objects, sum))%>% arrange(desc(num_objects)) ``` ::: I've removed the year column and combined each country data set so we have a flat rate of total objects launched. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 109 × 2 Entity num_objects 1 World 17263 2 United States 9632 3 Russia 3723 4 China 1051 5 United Kingdom 765 6 Japan 325 7 France 151 8 India 144 9 Germany 120 10 European Space Agency 104 # ℹ 99 more rows ``` ::: ::: The World has the most objects launched into space by far. Followed by the US, Russia, China and the UK. Note that these are objects launched exclusively by each countries government, and not necessarily objects launched on their soil, or all objects each country has participated in launching. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} outer_space_objects3 <- outer_space_objects2 outer_space_objects3$Entity[6:109] <- "Other" outer_space_objects3 %>% group_by(Entity)%>% summarise(across(num_objects, sum))%>% arrange(desc(num_objects)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 2 Entity num_objects 1 World 17263 2 United States 9632 3 Russia 3723 4 Other 2116 5 China 1051 6 United Kingdom 765 ``` ::: ::: I've combined all the other entities that weren't in the top five into an `Other` variable to make it easier to graph. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Project2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: World makes up over half of all objects launched into space.
Now, let's graph number of objects per year, faceting for the type of organization. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Project2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: It looks like private organizations launch significantly less objects than multinational organizations or individual countries. The highest producer of objects are multinational organizations. We're going to focus on multinational organizations and countries. # Multinational Organizations ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} objectsmult <- outer_space_objects %>% filter(Organization == "Multinational")%>% arrange(Entity) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Project2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: The world data is significantly skewing the rest of the data, lets remove it. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} objmult2 <- objectsmult %>% filter(Entity!="World") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Project2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Now that the World data is removed we can tell that the highest preforming Organization is the ESA and EU. This is most likely because Europe has strong unification as a continent. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `geom_line()`: Each group consists of only one observation. ℹ Do you need to adjust the group aesthetic? `geom_line()`: Each group consists of only one observation. ℹ Do you need to adjust the group aesthetic? ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Project2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `geom_line()`: Each group consists of only one observation. ℹ Do you need to adjust the group aesthetic? `geom_line()`: Each group consists of only one observation. ℹ Do you need to adjust the group aesthetic? ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Project2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-2.png){width=672} ::: ::: I provided a graph with and without the World entity to help visualize the data better. Not only have World based projects been in production for about 20 years longer than any other entity, they are more consistent and launch significantly more objects into space. # Countries First I'm going to sort all of the countries into continents to easier analyse the data. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(countrycode) countobj <- outer_space_objects %>% filter(Organization == "Country") countobj$Continent <- countrycode(sourcevar = countobj$Entity, origin = "country.name", destination = "continent") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Project2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Project2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-2.png){width=672} ::: ::: It looks like the Americas wins by a long shot, which I'm sure is mostly due to the US. Let's check. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} countobj2 <- countobj %>% filter(Continent=="Americas")%>% group_by(Entity)%>% summarise(across(num_objects, sum))%>% arrange(desc(num_objects)) countobj2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 15 × 2 Entity num_objects 1 United States 9632 2 Canada 102 3 Brazil 46 4 Uruguay 40 5 Argentina 22 6 Mexico 18 7 Chile 7 8 Peru 4 9 Venezuela 4 10 Colombia 3 11 Ecuador 2 12 Bolivia 1 13 Costa Rica 1 14 Guatemala 1 15 Paraguay 1 ``` ::: ::: # Conclusion I was pleasantly surprised to find that most of the objects that are launched into space are done collectively. I had some perception that this was the case, but I wasn't sure how it was labelled or kept as data, whether it was done by launching location, who worked on it the most or if it was considered a "group" effort and each country is mentioned separately.
